column2: There they came to a high gray stone wall, blocking their way, and stood still.
column3: There they came to a high gray stone wall, blocking their way, and stood still.

column2: You must climb, said Wild Star.

column2: CHAPTER X
column3: CHAPTER ten

column2: ON THE GRAY WALL
column3: ON THE GRAY WALL

column2: It was a very high wall that hid their mother, and at first glance it seemed impossible that they could ever climb it.
column3: It was a very high wall that hid their mother, and at first glance it seemed impossible that they could ever climb it.

column2: But Ivra did not stop to wonder.
column3: But Ivra did not stop to wonder.

column2: She ran up and down, hunting for a foothold.
column3: She ran up and down, hunting for a foothold.

column2: At last she reached the end of the wall and disappeared around the corner.
column3: At last she reached the end of the wall and disappeared around the corner.

column2: Eric and the Wind Creatures followed.
column3: Eric and the Wind Creatures followed.

column2: When they came up to her she had already found a place where the stones were laid a bit unevenly, one on the other, and was half way to the top, clinging with toes and fingers.
column3: When they came up to her she had already found a place where the stones were laid a bit unevenly, one on the other, and was half way to the top, clinging with toes and fingers.

column2: Bravo! cried the Wind Creatures.
column3: Bravo! cried the Wind Creatures.

column2: Eric went up after her, often slipping back and bruising and scratching his hands and knees, but as resolute as his playmate.
column3: Eric went up after her, often slipping back and bruising and scratching his hands and knees, but as resolute as his playmate.

column2: At last they gained the top.
column3: At last they gained the top.

column2: The Wind Creatures had flown up and were waiting for them there, sitting cross-legged with their purple wings folded down their backs.
column3: The Wind Creatures had flown up and were waiting for them there, sitting cross legged with their purple wings folded down their backs.

column2: The wall enclosed the garden of a very rich family.
column3: The wall enclosed the garden of a very rich family.

column2: It was a formal garden with straight walks, trellises, fountains, benches and neat flower beds laid out in squares and circles, now piled high with blossoming snow.
column3: It was a formal garden with straight walks, trellises, fountains, benches and neat flower beds laid out in squares and circles, now piled high with blossoming snow.

column2: Just as the children reached the top of the wall, the door into the garden from the stern gray mansion behind it opened and through it came three people.
column3: Just as the children reached the top of the wall, the door into the garden from the stern gray mansion behind it opened and through it came three people.

column2: First was a very tall lady all wrapped up in furs,--tails and heads of the poor animals that had been slain to make them hanging from her shoulders and down her back.
column3: First was a very tall lady all wrapped up in furs,--tails and heads of the poor animals that had been slain to make them hanging from her shoulders and down her back.

column2: Even the children could see that her face was sour in spite of all its smiling.
column3: Even the children could see that her face was sour in spite of all its smiling.

column2: Then came a young man in a stiff, funny hat, carrying a cane, beating up the snow flowers with it as he passed the flower beds.
column3: Then came a young man in a stiff, funny hat, carrying a cane, beating up the snow flowers with it as he passed the flower beds.

column2: And behind them walked--Helma, with her gaze on the ground.
column3: And behind them walked-Helma, with her gaze on the ground.

column2: That is why they did not know her at first, that and her very strange clothes.
column3: That is why they did not know her at first, that and her very strange clothes.

column2: She was dressed all in velvet and fur, and her arms up to her elbows were hidden in a huge white muff.
column3: She was dressed all in velvet and fur, and her arms up to her elbows were hidden in a huge white muff.

column2: She swayed as she walked on weird little high heels and the toes of her boots drew out to long points, almost like a goblin's.
column3: She swayed as she walked on weird little high heels and the toes of her boots drew out to long points, almost like a goblin's.

column2: Her hat was a velvet affair, so awkward and heavy it seemed to weigh down her head, and her candleflame hair was smothered under it.
column3: Her hat was a velvet affair, so awkward and heavy it seemed to weigh down her head, and her candleflame hair was smothered under it.

column2: Is it any wonder that they did not know her like that!
column3: Is it any wonder that they did not know her like that!

column2: But when she walked close under the wall and they heard her voice they knew her, and the Wind Creatures had to hold Ivra from jumping down and throwing herself into her arms.
column3: But when she walked close under the wall and they heard her voice they knew her, and the Wind Creatures had to hold Ivra from jumping down and throwing herself into her arms.

column2: Wait, they whispered.

column2: From their high place on the wall they could look down on the heads of the three people, and hear all they were saying.

column2: They had never learned that it is not fair to listen that way.

column2: From all Helma said they could plainly see she was a prisoner.

column2: She was pleading with the old woman.

column2: She was saying, "No, never, never, never, in a thousand days and years will I ever be happy here.
column3: She was saying, "No, never, never, never, in a thousand days and years will I ever be happy here.

column2: My place is in the forest.
column3: My place is in the forest.

column2: Oh, how these heels bother!"

column2: Silly girl! cried the old woman, smiling more than ever, and looking more disagreeable than ever at the same time.
column3: Silly girl! cried the old woman, smiling more than ever, and looking more disagreeable than ever at the same time.

column2: Your place is where you were born-in a fine house and wearing clothes like other people.	Your place is where you were born in a fine house and wearing clothes like other people.

column2: Heels indeed!
column3: Heels indeed!

column2: Did you expect them to do any thing else but bother?
column3: Did you expect them to do any thing else but bother?

column2: Mine have bothered for sixty years, but you haven't heard _me_ complain."

column2: Neither would I, Helma said, "if I didn't know about other kinds of shoes that don't hurt.
column3: Neither would I, Helma said, "if I didn't know about other kinds of shoes that don't hurt.

column2: Those sandals I wore when you caught me didn't hurt.
column3: Those sandals I wore when you caught me didn't hurt.

column2: Why can't I wear those, at least when I walk in the garden?"
column3: Why can't I wear those, at least when I walk in the garden?"

column2: Well, you might, began the old woman, a little more kindly, and smiling less, "if you promise always to put on the high heels before coming into the drawing room--"
column3: Well, you might, began the old woman, a little more kindly, and smiling less, "if you promise always to put on the high heels before coming into the drawing room-"

column2: No, said the young man sharply.

column2: I say that we give her no chance to escape.

column2: After she has been to a hundred or so balls and worn these beautiful and appropriate clothes long enough she'll be glad of her luck, and nothing could drag her into the forest.

column2: Believe me!"

column2: Now Helma stopped pleading, and laughed at the young man.
column3: Now Helma stopped pleading, and laughed at the young man.

column2: Do you think high heels, or even a hat that weighs down my head like this horrid one can keep me much longer from my little daughter, and that dear new little boy?	Do you think high heels, or even a hat that weighs down my head like this horrid one can keep me much longer from my little daughter, and that dear new little boy?

column2: What they are doing without me all this time--I wonder!" She stopped laughing to sigh.

column2: The old woman took her hand not unkindly.
column3: The old woman took her hand not unkindly.

column2: My poor, dear girl, she said, "how many times must I tell you it is only a dream, that house in the woods and the little girl and boy?
column3: My poor, dear girl, she said, "how many times must I tell you it is only a dream, that house in the woods and the little girl and boy?

column2: They aren't really there at all, you know.
column3: They aren't really there at all, you know.

column2: You have dreamed them.
column3: You have dreamed them.

column2: Come, cheer up.
column3: Come, cheer up.

column2: Be a brave girl.
column3: Be a brave girl.

column2: We have parties and good times enough here, if you will only get into the spirit of them, to make up for all your forest foolishness."
column3: We have parties and good times enough here, if you will only get into the spirit of them, to make up for all your forest foolishness."

column2: She is my little fairy daughter."
column3: She is my little fairy daughter."

column2: The wings of the Wind Creatures on the top of the wall rustled just then in a gust of cold north wind.

column2: Helma threw up her head as at a familiar sound, and her eyes slowly lifted to the faces of the children looking down.
column3: Helma threw up her head as at a familiar sound, and her eyes slowly lifted to the faces of the children looking down.

column2: But the old woman and the young man were not looking at her and so they noticed nothing.

column2: The young man said, "The neighbors have talked about us enough already for all your queer ideas and doings.

column3: But Helma laughed, her head thrown back, so that the children could look into her happy eyes and see the glow of her short hair under her grotesque hat.

column2: Keep your keys, cousin, she said, "and your old skylight keep shut tight as tight.

column2: The children went straight to the Tree Man's to tell him the news.

column2: Then the Tree Girl begged for a story, and Ivra told a World Story about the rivers,--how they go in search of their mother, the ocean, day and night, around mountains and through mountains, and across whole continents, and never stop until they find her,--and of the myriad presents they carry to her,--of the things they see and the things they do, as they flow searching.
column3: Then the Tree Girl begged for a story, and Ivra told a World Story about the rivers,--how they go in search of their mother, the ocean, day and night, around mountains and through mountains, and across whole continents, and never stop until they find her,--and of the myriad presents they carry to her,--of the things they see and the things they do, as they flow searching.

column2: It was a long story.
column3: It was a long story.

column2: And almost before the end the little story teller had fallen asleep with her head tipped back against the Tree Man's chest.
column3: And almost before the end the little story teller had fallen asleep with her head tipped back against the Tree Man's chest.

column2: They spent that night in the tree, and that was good, for a storm had risen outside, and it was bitter cold in the forest.
